## GAD-7 vs ARBQ

GAD-7 vs ARBQ Diving into psychology research often entails the intricate task of harmonising numerous questionnaires. An emergent challenge lies in comparing instruments like GAD-7, designed to assess the severity of generalised anxiety disorder, and the Anxiety-Related Behaviours Questionnaire (ARBQ), which probes a more diverse range of anxieties. The process of manual comparison can be painstakingly time-consuming and often laced with subjective biases. Fortunately, tools like Harmony have developed to ameliorate this exact issue, making the comparison of GAD-7 vs ARBQ a seemingly effortless task. Harmony leverages natural language processing and generative AI models, taking an especially useful approach when addressing GAD-7 vs ARBQ. This software compares each individual item of the questionnaires, providing a percentage match between them all, thus facilitating simultaneous within-study and cross-study comparisons. Harmony not only supports researchers in comparing GAD-7 vs ARBQ but also allows items comparison in multiple languages, an invaluable resource in an increasingly global research environment. Thus, in advancing psychology research, the GAD-7 vs ARBQ comparison through Harmony is a highly recommended tool. Harmonyâ€™s database is equipped with these instruments, yet it also integrates a user-friendly platform where you can drop your own questionnaires. With this advanced tool, never again wonder about the alignment between the 'Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge' in GAD-7 and 'Is often extremely upset or distressed when parent leaves wound up or stressed' in ARBQ. Let Harmony do the legwork in your GAD-7 vs ARBQ comparison.

## Questions in GAD-7

|   No. | GAD-7 English                                                                                                                                      |
|------:|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|     1 | Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge                                                                                                               |
|     2 | Not being able to stop or control worrying                                                                                                         |
|     3 | Worrying too much about different things                                                                                                           |
|     4 | Trouble relaxing                                                                                                                                   |
|     5 | Being so restless that it is hard to sit still                                                                                                     |
|     6 | Becoming easily annoyed or irritable                                                                                                               |
|     7 | Feeling afraid, as if something awful might happen                                                                                                 |
|     8 | If you checked any problems, how difficult have they made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people? |
